data.title: About the Playwright: Ah, Wilderness!
data.meta_description: Tony Award-winning theater at the Utah Shakespeare Festival in Cedar City, Utah.
data.text:
By Elaine Pilkington

Eugene OâNeillâs work was shaped by an early life filled with adversities, and his greatest successes were the result of or a reaction to many of those hardships. In 1912, OâNeillâs brief marriage to Kathleen Jenkins ended, he attempted suicide at âJimmie-the-Priestâsâ saloon, and he entered a sanatorium to recover from tuberculosis (Normand Berlin in Benetâs Readerâs Encyclopedia of American Literature ed. by George Perkins, Barbara Perkins, and Phillip Leininger [New York: HarperCollins Publisher, 1991], 808 09). OâNeillâs downward slide had begun in 1907 when he left Princeton after one academic year. Having failed to take his required exams, he was dropped for academic reasons and misbehavior, throwing âa rock in the stationmasterâs window during a drunken spreeâ (Berlin, 809).

In the intervening years, OâNeill was a secretary for a mail-order firm in New York, an assistant manager for a touring theatrical company, a prospector for gold in Honduras, a frequent seaman, and a reporter. He worked at various occupations in Argentina, âbut usually lived the life of a bum on the waterfront, sleeping on benches, and scrounging for alcohol and foodâ (Berlin, 809), and he âwent to South Africa, tending mules on a cattle steamerâ (Joseph Wood Krutch, intr. Nine Plays by Eugene OâNeill [New York: Liveright, Inc. 1932], xiii).

In contrast, the time OâNeill spent in the sanatorium was a period of self-discovery and rebirth. âHe began to mine his own psyche, searching for the answers to his lifeâs meaning, trying to face the sometimes painful truth about himself and the raw facts of his past.â Rather than being overwhelmed by his illness, he felt that his conquest of it âhad empowered him to challenge fate on other levelsâand dare to believe he could win.â Five years before his death, OâNeill âwas still eager to stress that if he had not been forced to look hard at himself in the sanatorium, he might never have become a playwrightâ (Arthur and Barbara Gelb, OâNeill: Life with Monte Cristo [New York: Applause Books, 2000], 388-89).

Life in the sanatorium also gave him opportunities for reading and study. âDuring that period he began to read seriously every play he could lay hands on: the Greeks, the Elizabethansâpractically all the classicsâand of course all the moderns. Ibsen and Strindberg, especially Strindbergâ (Berlin, 808). OâNeill credited Strindbergâs work with giving him âthe vision of what modern drama could be, and first . . . [inspiring him] with the urge to write for the theaterâ (Gelb, 404).

After five months at Gaylord Farm Sanatorium, OâNeill had gained sixteen pounds and was certified fit to leave (Gelb, 392). Returning to the family summer home in New London, Connecticut, he began writing one-act plays, eventually seeking âhelp on technical mattersâ by enrolling in âProfessor George Pierce Bakerâs famous drama workshop at Harvardâ (Paul M. Cubeta, Modern Drama for Analysis [New York: Holt, Rhinehart and Winston, 1962], 153). In 1916 OâNeill became affiliated with the Provincetown Players who produced his plays written from 1915 to 1920 (Kenneth Macgowan, intro. Famous American Plays of the 1920s [New York: Dell Publishing Co., 1959], 25). Beyond the Horizon, his first important full-length play, was produced in 1920 and became a Broadway success (Berlin, 810). In the 1920s and 1930s, OâNeill wrote the majority of his best known plays, such as The Emperor Jones, The Hairy Ape, Desire under the Elms, Mourning Becomes Electra, and Ah, Wilderness!, and established himself as âAmericaâs outstanding dramatistâ of the period, receiving the Pulitzer Prize for Beyond the Horizon (1920), Anna Christie (1922), and Strange Interlude (1928) (Cubeta, 153). (The Pulitzer Prize for Long Dayâs Journey into Night was awarded posthumously in 1957.) In 1936 he received the Nobel Prize, âa feat no other American playwright had been able to accomplishâ (“Eugene O’Neill,â (www.imagination.com/moonstruck/clsc34.html).

OâNeillâs tempestuous early years served as material for his plays: his own experiences emerge in his work about the sea, his saloon days influence Anna Christie and The Iceman Cometh, and his stay in the sanatorium provides much of the plot and many of the characters in The Straw. But clearly the greatest autobiographical force in his work was his family and his relationship with them.

OâNeill was born on October 16, 1888, in a hotel room on Broadway. His famous father, James OâNeill, had traded a glowing career as a Shakespearean actor for a more financially secure role, touring in the lead role of The Count of Monte Cristo (Berlin, 808). Because OâNeillâs mother accompanied her husband, Eugene and his older brother, Jamie, attended boarding schools from an early age. The strain of this lifestyle on Mrs. OâNeill, the loss of her second son at age two, and a difficult birth with Eugene perhaps contributed to her addiction to morphine. Brother Jamie became an alcoholic whose story, softened by a gentle death, is told in A Moon for the Misbegotten.
